What is a Tsunami?

Tsunamis are extremely large waves that hit the shoreline.

Due to their sheer size they are known to cause a lot of infrastructural damage wherever they appear.

A few facts about tsunamis from my Earth Science class.

  • "Tsunami" is a Japanese word that has characters "Tsu" - harbor and "nameh" - wave, so it literally means Harbor-wave.
  • Tsunami are caused by a sudden and large displacement of ocean waters.
    • (We'll talk about this in detail)
  • Tsunamis don't go in one direction, they radiate outward in all directions.
  • Some tsunamis are so large that they travel through entire ocean basins.
  • Tsunamis cause dangerous coastal flooding and can last from an hour to several days!

Where do Tsunamis occur?

Tsunamis occur the most in the area of the Earth called the ring of fire.

The ring of fire is an area where Earth's tectonic plates collide.

üåèWe learn about tectonic plates and earthquakes here.


Image from Wikipedia - Ring Of Fire.

The ring of fire is a place where a lot of earthquakes occur.

And it's called the ring of fire due to the amount of Volcanoes that result from tectonic plate motions.

üåã We learn about Volcanoes here.

Tsunamis are known to occur in areas such as Japan and pacific asian islands.

Due to Japan's location, Japan is hit by a tsunami at least once every year!

Even though we mostly associate tsunamis with Japan, Mexico has also been hit Tsunamis in the past.

Though not frequent tsunamis have hit the coast of Mexico causing trouble for many who live near the shoreline.

How does a Tsunami occur?

Tsunamis are a result of sudden outbursts of energy that displace the ocean waters.

Such outbursts of energy can be caused by

  1. Earthquakes sudden shift of tectonic plates.
  2. Landslides sudden shift of land shifts the ocean waters.
  3. Volcanic activity AKA volcanic explosions under the ocean.
  4. Even meteorites can cause tsunamis, as they carry a lot of energy release at once into the ocean.

Take a look at this video.

Here we can see two tectonic plates colliding and the plate that staying on top slips releasing a LOT of energy.

This plate boundary is called a subduction, as one plate sub-ducts AKA goes under the other plate. The plate that remains on top tries to resist the push and over time builds up energy. That plate then slips releasing all of that stored up energy displacing the water above. The water then rushes outward in all directions. And If powerful enough it reaches the shoreline.

How often do tsunamis happen?

According to tsunami.gov "tsunamis that cause damage or deaths near their source occur approximately twice per year."

How to prepare for a tsunami?

If you don't live anywhere near a shoreline you are mostly from Tsunamis.

If you reside near a shoreline no matter how far from the ring of fire you are located, you must look out for a few things.

  1. If you feel an earthquake.
  2. If you hear a loud roar from the ocean (like a train or an airplane).
  3. Water moving back unusually far and revealing the ocean floor.

Then run! Get as high up as you can! Leave your belongings, help others to get as high up as possible.

Other than looking out for these signs and listening to your local authorities there isn't much you can do. If there area you're in is known for tsunamis scout out a route to the nearest tallest building.

Tsunamis occur at random times from earthquakes. And at the moment we do not posses technology that is capable of predicting an earthquake.

Other causes of Tsunamis from volcanoes, meteorites or landslides can not be predicted either.

üåä A live map for Tsunamis and more information on tsunamis.

What is a Flood?

Flood is a sudden income of large amounts of water that covers land that normally dry in water.

What causes Floods?

  1. Tsunamis - due to sheer force and amount of water that moves inland.
  2. Heavy rain - less devastating, but still can displace a large number of people and leave many without a place to call home.
  3. Human activity - due to ocean levels rising from Global Warming, most areas are more prone to flooding due to more water being in the ocean.

Where are floods the most common?

Since it can rain almost anywhere in the world, floods can also occur anywhere.

But some areas are much more likely to get flooded. Areas that already get Tsunamis or areas close to oceans are at most risk.

Source of image above.


From the map above we can see that can occur anywhere.

But if we take a look at Australia (Bottom Right) we can see that mostly the shoreline was effected.

Any place that is low on elevation and is close to a large amount of water is prone to flooding.

How dangerous are floods?

We have already discussed on how Tsunamis occur and what to look out for.

A Tsunami is one of the most devastating hazards that cause a flood.

According to National Weather Service "A mere 6 inches of fast-moving flood water can knock over an adult. It takes just 12 inches of rushing water to carry away most cars and just 2 feet of rushing water can carry away SUVs and trucks. It is NEVER safe to drive or walk into flood waters."

National Weather Service Link

What can you do to prepare?

  1. Have water purification/filtering tools ready. Or if possible find a clean source of drinkable water.
  2. Understand your area and figure out high grounds near you to reallocate for your safety.
  3. Floods occur suddenly and you or others will get hurt. So have a first aid kid ready.
  4. Have some emergency food cans stocked up in case of emergency situations.
Wateroam - disaster relief company.
